edibility: Absolutely! Fruity fragance and delicate flavor.
foundNear: Near conifers and oaks. Often in groups, but not clusters.
keyFeatures: Well spaced gills, same color as cap or lighter. Orange, bald, concave cap. Solid stalk.

edibility: Delicious! Some prefer it to the chanterelle.
foundNear: Near pines, conifers, tanoak, and manzanita.
keyFeatures: Well spaced gills, same color as cap or lighter. White, bald, concave cap. Solid stalk. Entire mushroom is white, but can be orange where bruised.

edibility: Edible, but not as good as other Chanterelles.
foundNear: On ground in wet conifer forests or bogs.
keyFeatures: Few, well spaced gills. Dull orange to tan to dark brown in color, bald cap with a central depression. Stalk hollow. Cap is not sticky or slimey.

edibility: Delicious, but often riddled with maggots.
foundNear: On ground in mossy conifer forests or in mixed woods. Often in clusters.
keyFeatures: White flesh. Solid stalk. Mature cap is yellow to tan, no scales. Underside purplish with wrinkles or ridges from stalk to base.

edibility: Not recommended. Can make you ill.
keyFeatures: Vase shaped. Cap is red to orange. Surface of cap has scales. Underside is hitish to yellowish with veins and wrinkles running down the stalk.

edibility: Delicious! The most flavorful of the Chanterelles.
foundNear: On the ground in forests. Common, but hard to see in shadows. Fruits late in the season.
keyFeatures: Trumpetlike mushroom, cap hallow extends to the base of the stalk. Black when moist, brown when dry. Underside is grey with wrinkles, but no gills. Stalk is grey.
